repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Wanted to see if we could modernize this a bit - looks like a lot of the documentation still wants users to use Python2.7 alongside this.

Not sure everything here is 100% correct but I think still represents progress over what is there today. You can get a working Cython debugger image and mini instructions from this Docker repo:

https://hub.docker.com/repository/docker/willayd/cython-debug

comment_data.body: Wanted to avoid shadowing the breakpoint keyword, which didn't exist when this code was first written
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -776,8 +776,8 @@ def _break_pyx(self, name):
 
         if (cython_module.filename, lineno) in cython_module.lineno_cy2c:
             c_lineno = cython_module.lineno_cy2c[cython_module.filename, lineno]
-            breakpoint = '%s:%s' % (cython_module.c_filename, c_lineno)
-            gdb.execute('break ' + breakpoint)
+            breakpnt = '%s:%s' % (cython_module.c_filename, c_lineno)

comment_data.body: In cases where you ran `cy locals` and there were none to report the call to `max` would fail with `ValueError: max() arg is an empty sequence`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1172,7 +1172,10 @@ def invoke(self, args, from_tty):
             return
 
         local_cython_vars = cython_function.locals
-        max_name_length = len(max(local_cython_vars, key=len))
+        if local_cython_vars:

comment_data.body: All of the updates in this file are upstreamed from the Python3.7 branch of CPython
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -628,7 +628,7 @@ class PyCFunctionObjectPtr(PyObjectPtr):
     _typename = 'PyCFunctionObject'
 
     def proxyval(self, visited):
-        m_ml = self.field('m_ml')  # m_ml is a (PyMethodDef*)
+        m_ml = self.field('m_ml') # m_ml is a (PyMethodDef*)

comment_data.body: The original link here has a note that it is broken and unmaintained, so figured harmless enough to remove
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9,19 +9,15 @@ Debugging your Cython program
 Cython comes with an extension for the GNU Debugger that helps users debug
 Cython code. To use this functionality, you will need to install gdb 7.2 or
 higher, built with Python support (linked to Python 2.6 or higher).
-The debugger supports debuggees with versions 2.6 and higher. For Python 3,
-code should be built with Python 3 and the debugger should be run with
-Python 2 (or at least it should be able to find the Python 2 Cython
-installation). Note that in recent versions of Ubuntu, for instance, ``gdb``
-installed with ``apt-get`` is configured with Python 3. On such systems, the
-proper configuration of ``gdb`` can be obtained by downloading the ``gdb``
-source, and then running::
-
-    ./configure --with-python=python2
+For optimal results, you should configure gdb from source and use the --with-python
+configuration flag. ::
+
+    ./configure --with-python=python3
     make
     sudo make install
 
-Installing the Cython debugger can be quite tricky. `This installation script and example code <https://gitlab.com/volkerweissmann/cygdb_installation>`_ might be useful.

comment_data.body:
I think a ternary expression is simpler here.
```suggestion
        max_name_length = len(max(local_cython_vars, key=len)) if local_cython_vars else 0
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1172,7 +1172,10 @@ def invoke(self, args, from_tty):
             return
 
         local_cython_vars = cython_function.locals
-        max_name_length = len(max(local_cython_vars, key=len))
+        if local_cython_vars:
+            max_name_length = len(max(local_cython_vars, key=len))
+        else:
+            max_name_length = 0

comment_data.body: This looks like a change that breaks older Python versions. We should better keep all four names.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1572,8 +1572,8 @@ def is_other_python_frame(self):
         if not caller:
             return False
 
-        if (caller.startswith('cfunction_vectorcall_') or
-            caller == 'cfunction_call'):
+        if caller in ('_PyCFunction_FastCallDict',
+                      '_PyCFunction_FastCallKeywords'):

comment_data.body: It feels like we could still say a bit more about ways to get this working with recent Python 3 deployments. Most Linux installations these days might actually work out of the box with gdb and Python 3. Users shouldn't have to build anything as basic as gdb from sources.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9,19 +9,15 @@ Debugging your Cython program
 Cython comes with an extension for the GNU Debugger that helps users debug
 Cython code. To use this functionality, you will need to install gdb 7.2 or
 higher, built with Python support (linked to Python 2.6 or higher).
-The debugger supports debuggees with versions 2.6 and higher. For Python 3,
-code should be built with Python 3 and the debugger should be run with
-Python 2 (or at least it should be able to find the Python 2 Cython
-installation). Note that in recent versions of Ubuntu, for instance, ``gdb``
-installed with ``apt-get`` is configured with Python 3. On such systems, the
-proper configuration of ``gdb`` can be obtained by downloading the ``gdb``
-source, and then running::
-
-    ./configure --with-python=python2
+For optimal results, you should configure gdb from source and use the --with-python
+configuration flag. ::

comment_data.body: Yea I couldn't find good info on this, but as far as I could tell gdb needed to be compiled with a reference to the Python installation you want to use to debug. I wasn't able to use a virtual environment and get it to work
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9,19 +9,15 @@ Debugging your Cython program
 Cython comes with an extension for the GNU Debugger that helps users debug
 Cython code. To use this functionality, you will need to install gdb 7.2 or
 higher, built with Python support (linked to Python 2.6 or higher).
-The debugger supports debuggees with versions 2.6 and higher. For Python 3,

-installation). Note that in recent versions of Ubuntu, for instance, ``gdb``
-installed with ``apt-get`` is configured with Python 3. On such systems, the
-proper configuration of ``gdb`` can be obtained by downloading the ``gdb``
-source, and then running::

+For optimal results, you should configure gdb from source and use the --with-python
+configuration flag. ::

comment_data.body:
Hmm interesting. Actually looking at this again the previous code in the diff matches what is in Python's main branch. What I have here came from the 3.7 branch, so I'm guessing the previous Cython code was upstreamed from a newer version than 3.7

Do you still want all 4 or should we just match what's in Python today?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1572,8 +1572,8 @@ def is_other_python_frame(self):
         if not caller:
             return False
 
-        if (caller.startswith('cfunction_vectorcall_') or
-            caller == 'cfunction_call'):
+        if caller in ('_PyCFunction_FastCallDict',
+                      '_PyCFunction_FastCallKeywords'):

comment_data.body: The more Python versions we can support, the better.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1572,8 +1572,8 @@ def is_other_python_frame(self):
         if not caller:
             return False
 
-        if (caller.startswith('cfunction_vectorcall_') or
-            caller == 'cfunction_call'):
+        if caller in ('_PyCFunction_FastCallDict',
+                      '_PyCFunction_FastCallKeywords'):

comment_data.body: Not sure if there was an easier way to exclude things from pycodestyle
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1823,6 +1823,9 @@ def runTest(self):
         paths = []
         for codedir in source_dirs:
             paths += glob.glob(os.path.join(self.cython_dir, codedir + "/**/*.py"), recursive=True)
+
+        # remove any files vendored from CPython
+        paths = [x for x in paths if not "vendored" in x]

comment_data.body:
OK it may not be as strict as this documentation shows, but it is not as easy as using the system gdb unfortunately. It seems like when calling a system-installed gdb from a virtual environment like conda, gdb loses track of python being called from a local environment and falls back to the system python

```sh
(pandas-dev) willayd@willayd-Lemur-Pro:~/clones/pandas$ which python
/home/willayd/mambaforge/envs/pandas-dev/bin/python
(pandas-dev) willayd@willayd-Lemur-Pro:~/clones/pandas$ cygdb
GNU gdb (Ubuntu 14.0.50.20230907-0ubuntu1) 14.0.50.20230907-git
Copyright (C) 2023 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <http://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html>
This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it.
There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.
Type "show copying" and "show warranty" for details.
This GDB was configured as "x86_64-linux-gnu".
Type "show configuration" for configuration details.
For bug reporting instructions, please see:
<https://www.gnu.org/software/gdb/bugs/>.
Find the GDB manual and other documentation resources online at:
    <http://www.gnu.org/software/gdb/documentation/>.

For help, type "help".
Type "apropos word" to search for commands related to "word".
There was an error in Python code originating from the file /home/willayd/clones/cython/Cython/Debugger/Cygdb.py
It used the Python interpreter /usr/bin/python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 11, in <module>
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'Cython'
```

Installing gdb into the virtual environment resolves the issue. Not sure yet if this is a Cython or gdb problem mixing up the python installations
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9,19 +9,15 @@ Debugging your Cython program
 Cython comes with an extension for the GNU Debugger that helps users debug
 Cython code. To use this functionality, you will need to install gdb 7.2 or
 higher, built with Python support (linked to Python 2.6 or higher).
-The debugger supports debuggees with versions 2.6 and higher. For Python 3,
-code should be built with Python 3 and the debugger should be run with
-Python 2 (or at least it should be able to find the Python 2 Cython
-installation). Note that in recent versions of Ubuntu, for instance, ``gdb``
-installed with ``apt-get`` is configured with Python 3. On such systems, the
-proper configuration of ``gdb`` can be obtained by downloading the ``gdb``
-source, and then running::
-
-    ./configure --with-python=python2
+For optimal results, you should configure gdb from source and use the --with-python
+configuration flag. ::

comment_data.body:
Looking at the gdb source code there is also some compile-time compatability for versions prior to 3.9. This particular instance probably just deserves a note in the documentation, but there is a risk for that happening in the future 

https://sourceware.org/git/?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=blob;f=gdb/python/python.c;h=8a36673a3e4c0bef8533d259d8c13118e650df1a;hb=refs/heads/master#l2213

title: Update Cython Debugger
